text: Just a brief statement on how you became a professional writer, the background that led you to it Well it's, you know, everybody's story is a long story It's much easier for other people to summarize you than it is for you to summarize yourself I conceived in college the ambition to be a professional writer of fiction It was a number of years before I stumbled into writing fantasy and that was a crucial thing for me because my writing got a great deal better when I started to write fantasy but that had been about 8 years I had been writing as hard as I knew how for 8 years before I started on fantasy and from the time I started writing fantasy until I finally achieved a publication of some kind was another 5 years so I had a a 13-year apprenticeship in a sense and then it's been only since then that I've been able to support myself as a writer. Did you grow up reading science fiction? Well, actually no. And not for any other reason than in terms of what I call a historical accident. I was living in India because my parents were medical missionaries to India and we simply got a very erratic supply of books. There was no one particular kind of thing that we got except mystery novels. Missionaries love to read mystery novels. I don't know quite why that is. But other than that, it was a random sampling of everything. I read Leon Urus and the Hardy Boys at the same time, and I read Bamba the Jungle Boy, and I read James Michener, and a whole range of things, whatever I could get my hands on. Now, I loved every science fiction novel that I got my hands on, of which I can remember every one. There were three. I read three by the time I was a high school graduate. One was Alfred Bester's The Star Is My Destination. One was A.J. Boudry's Rogue Moon. And one was Theodore Sturgeon's More Than Human. Now, it's just an accident that I happened to get to read three classics in the only three science fiction books I read. They made a great impression on me, but that was all there was. Now, I came to the United States at the end of my high school days to start college, and I wanted to read more science fiction, but I didn't know any people who read it. So I didn't know any place to get information about what was worth reading. And what I would do is wander into a drugstore and pick up a science fiction book. And you can get some remarkably bad books doing that. And the things that I picked up in the first couple of years in drugstores were so terrible that I stopped reading science fiction. And in fact, I didn't start reading science fiction again until I was finally in a position where I knew people who could make recommendations to separate out the real garbage from the good stuff. Were the Chronicles of Thomas' Covenant, the first Chronicles, was that your first published work? Yes. Well, actually, I had a couple of letters to the editor published in the Avengers comic books back in the late 60s, but that was the only other time my name was in print. I heard you talk about this, I think it was yesterday. You did have a lot of trouble getting that accepted. I had a great deal of trouble getting my break. Lord Filesbane was rejected by every fiction publisher in the United States and also by all the magazines that did serializations at that time and also by several agents. By the time I had finished having that book rejected, it had been rejected 47 times. It took three and a half years or so for me to do that. It was a very difficult process. And in a lot of ways, I was saved. by happenstance. After being, I went through the alphabet from A to Z with publishers, and when I got to Z, I didn't know what else to do. I thought that it might work if I tried to send my book to British publishers. I mean, I didn't have anywhere else to turn at that point. So I sent away for a directory of British publishing so that I could begin going from A to Z in England. And while I was waiting for that book to come, I just couldn't bear to let my manuscript sit. So I resubmitted it to Ballantyne Books. And the only reason I did that was because they published Lord of the Rings, which meant to me that they were a profitable company. If they were making some money, there's at least a slightly better chance that they'd take a wing on somebody like me. What I did not know was that since the last time I had submitted my book to Ballantyne they had fired their entire editorial staff and had all the new people and essentially what they had was Lester and Judy Lynn Del Rey and the delrays jumped on Lord Falls Bay as soon as they got it they knew almost immediately that they wanted to publish this material changed my life but up until then it was an extremely difficult process this was unfair question I'm sure it's too general to be really fair one but was there a particular impetus behind that novel? Well, that is pretty gentle. I don't know what kind of impetus you're talking about. When you started to write, was there something in your mind that said, I want to write a novel of this type about Thomas Covenant, who's a leper and so forth? Well, the key thing for me about The Chronicles of Thomas Covenant was that my inspiration for it came from the end. The first idea that occurred for me for that book was for the climax of The Power That Preserves. Now, when I got a story going, I had an entire story ready to tell. And from that point of view, the impetus that got me going on Lord Files Bane was the climax of The Power That Preserves. And that has been my pattern in all the Covenant books is that I have worked them all backwards. I mean, I don't write them backwards, but I plan them and arrange them backwards. The thing that inspires me to write the story comes at the end. So with the second Chronicles, it was the climax of White Gold Wielder that convinced me that I wanted to write a second Chronicles. And essentially, my method is that I have this climactic scene in mind, and I have to answer the simple questions like, who are these guys and how did they get into this mess? And I plan backwards on that basis. Well, in order for that to happen, these things must have happened first. And if those things must have happened first, then these kinds of people must have been doing those kinds of things. And I arrange everything backwards until I get to a point where I can start writing, which means that the one thing that's absolutely clear to me the whole time when I'm working on these things, I know where I'm going. I know exactly what the purpose of all these events is. It's going to produce that result, which you as a reader will finally come to at the end of 1,500 pages or whatever. And in the case of the first Chronicles, it was that climactic scene where Thomas Covenant, who has been rejecting the importance of his fantasy experience, comes face to face with Lord Fowle. And the fact that he disbelieves in some way in the reality of the fantasy gives him the emotional power to not be crushed by Lord Phowel. He knows he doesn't need to be overwhelmed by evil because he denies its external reality. I mean, he knows there's evil in him, but he doesn't have to be overwhelmed by this externalization of evil. And that makes it possible for him to win. Well, I knew that was where I was going the entire time I worked on the first trilogy. Okay. I think in one of your glossaries at the end of one of the books, you had the land, you had it defined as a focal region of the Earth. Yeah. You didn't have a particular spot or a where that the land is supposed to be located then. Well, I know it's on a globe. You know, I mean, this is a world, and the land is only, obviously it's only a small continental portion of an entire world. When you get into the second chronicles of Thomas' Covenant and people start voyaging around, you at least get some sense that there are lots of other things going on in the world too. My perception of it is that the land is kind of like the arena in which the crucial issues for the whole world are fought out. And although they have implications and ramifications which affect events in other parts of the world and different things happen maybe because of what's happening in the land, but that everything focuses there. Now this is, you know, it's a subtle question in some ways, and it's crucial in others. In the One Tree, the characters, the Elohim, who consider themselves to be very godlike, if not God itself, one problem for them is that the crucial events are happening somewhere else. And they think, I mean, obviously since we're crucial, if what's happening to you were really important, it would have been happening here instead of way over there. and that leads them into some decisions of questionable ethics. But for the thrust of the Covenant books as a whole, it's certainly true that the land is where the main battles are being fought and other stuff feeds into that but is not central. Hey, Covenant, at least in my experience with fantasy, I imagine for a lot of readers too, Covenant is sort of an anti-hero. You know, being a leper for one reason, but also being a, doesn't want to be a hero in the first place. Why pick somebody that was not in the traditional? Well, for one thing, you know, I mean, I wasn't aware of the tradition. I had read Lord of the Rings, but other than that I hadn't read much fantasy myself. So I wasn't making a conscious decision to go for or against anything normal. I was just trying to deal with something that seemed to me to be exciting and appropriate. Now, for me, the story started with the climax of the power that preserves. I have an unbeliever confronting the evil principle and rising above it. Well, I had that idea in my head for like three years before I ever had, before I could figure out who those guys were and how they got into that mess. That original idea, although it was very powerful to me, was also static. There was no story attached. I got a story when it occurred to me that the person who was going to go from the real world to the fantasy world and reject the fantasy world in favor of the real world should be somebody whose real world is unbearable and whose fantasy world is terrific. I mean, look at it the other way around. Suppose you have a terrific real life. And you have these rotten fantasies. if you then say I don't care about the fantasy I'm going to stick with reality what does that mean you know I mean you just that's normal self-interest anybody anybody who has a terrible time in their nightmares and a wonderful time in the rest of their life is going to prefer the rest of their life it only becomes a moral statement when you have somebody who really hates their life because their life is terrible and their dreams are just wonderful and they still say, I'm going to reject the dream because I know the difference and even though reality is terrible, I'm going to still affirm reality. Now that, you know, may seem a little unbalanced or crazy to some people, but it is a moral statement of some kind because there's no self-interest in it. It's not something that you do to make yourself feel better. It's something that you do as an ideal or as a belief, a religious belief. And, of course, whose real life could be lousier than a leper's. Now, as soon as I thought of that, then I had a story. I had a fantasy world, because all I had to do was invent a fantasy world that is the direct opposite of being a leper. And I had, you know, everything fell into place for me as soon as I thought of that kind of thing. Now, I never intended that as an anti-hero kind of situation. From my point of view, the only thing that makes Covenant an antihero is that he doesn't want to be a hero. He's afraid of being a hero. But he is a hero. From my point of view. And I think most of my readers eventually get sucked into the point, even though they don't like him in the beginning. First they start to admit that he's got some reasons for what he does and then they start grudgingly to respect what he's doing. And before you know it, people end up liking him and identifying with him as if he were a normal hero. and that's certainly the way it is for me I cared a lot about this character from the very beginning and I never worked with him as something that I would call anti-anything I knew he was having a tough time I knew it was rotten to be in the position that he was in and I knew from various kinds of studies and research what sorts of psychological problems people who suffer from leprosy develop what does it feel like to be despised by everybody around you for something that has nothing to do with what you did or didn't do. You just got this disease, you don't know why, everybody hates you. That exerts a tremendous psychological stress and it doesn't make people beautiful. You don't become a nice guy just because you got leprosy. The pressure brings, any kind of pressure, brings out the flaws in human nature. That's where you find out that there are areas where you're weak and there are areas where you're not very graceful is when somebody puts a lot of pressure on you and you start to get a little nasty and you start to get a little impatient and you start to do this and start to do that. It seemed obvious to me, particularly at the beginning, that Koffman is under tremendous kinds of psychological and emotional pressure and he's not going to be a very likable guy. But what's going to happen, and of course I knew this all along, what's going to happen is that in the course of coping with this dilemma, he was going to essentially reintegrate his whole personality and become a constructive individual who does know what he cares about and who does love other people and who is willing to fight for that. So from my point of view, there was never any identification problem. I identified with him a lot from the beginning. For a reader, it's different. A reader doesn't know where I'm going. And so they have to kind of evaluate things as it goes along. And for many readers, in the beginning, covenant is just very obnoxious. then later they learn to kind of understand him a bit. I guess to me, one of the paradoxes I guess it's a paradox that all six volumes is based upon is the idea that Covenant's power, his ability to combat despite Lord Fowl, is simply the fact that he is a leper and does have such a I guess a lousy life in the real world. That gives him a strength. Yeah, it gives him an emotional strength. what passes for magic in the Covenant books really is just an external expression of personality. The strength for magic always comes from inside the individual in this kind of world. And what creates emotional strength is what makes magic. like Lord Morum, who it becomes in the first Chronicles becomes the strongest of the lords, really, and does something that nobody else has been able to do in the end when he when he kills the giant raver that's attacking them. You know, what's really an issue for there is emotional strength. It's not it's not that you that you know more than somebody else does you know more spells than somebody else does or you've studied a different book of Arcana and have learned different kinds of magic or anything else. In this kind of world, magic doesn't hinge on that sort of thing. It hinges on the strengths and weaknesses of your own personality. And that's where the danger comes from of course because people who have that susceptibility to pressure to where like Kevin, they crack when things get too bad. Then they fall into despair and you get the same people who perform the ritual of desecration. The key issue is the personality of the person who has the power. or their personality structure, how strong or how weak they are. And what Covenant becomes over the course of these six books is this incredibly strong personality. And eventually, he becomes such a strong personality that in certain ways he doesn't need magic anymore. You'll find this when you've read through to the end of White Gold Wilder, That he dominates situations without using magic anymore because he has become such a strong structure internally, emotionally. i imagine um one of the joys of being a fantasy writer is in naming things i've always been impressed with your your the way you pick names for things and i wondered if that was something that comes naturally to you or you work at it or well i'm always a little embarrassed because traditionally um i mean if you assume that the tradition is tolkien then there's really a background for names certainly in Tolkien as he evolved an entire language of Elvish and worked out immensely elaborate structures which backup the names I have never been able to do that As a matter of fact I have trouble with foreign languages of any kind and became that close to flunking college German and stuff I do it by ear it's a very much intuitive kind of process for me Now, there are situations in which I beg, borrow, or steal words that mean something that I use for names. Like, for example, all the names of the ravers are words that have meaning. And I use those words because they mean something, but also because those words have the right sound to my ear for what I want. So in those situations, the name has to meet two criteria. The meaning has to be appropriate, and it still has to sound right. Other than that, I do it by sound. Certain kinds of combinations of sounds and whatnot sound good and strong and positive to me. And they sound like good guys. And other combinations of sounds sound like bad guys. You know, I make it up. I try to make it up consistently, obviously. Now, for example, all the giants have names which are combinations of normal words. Salt, heart, foam, follower. You know, those are all English words and you just string them together. So obviously when I'm making up names for my characters, I'm not going to make up that kind of name for one giant and then make up a completely different nonsense syllable kind of name for another giant. All the giants have the same kind of names. As it happens, the ramen, the people in the first trilogy who work with the horses, they all have names based on Indian words that I knew when I was a kid growing up in Indian. I just needed some sort of principle to help me pull it together so that I'm sure I'd be consistent about that name. So all those people have names that are based on Indian words. the bloodguard and the hiru-chai all have names of certain, sometimes they have two syllables more often than not they're one syllable words, you know, brin, kale, kier you know, and they're all words that seem to me to they're full of consonants, they're fairly strong sounding, but they're not words that that would carry any direct meaning in English you know, so I follow patterns, but I am doing it doing it by ear. I would imagine too that the name covenant has meaning, doesn't it? Oh, well, of course. You know, I have my religious background and everything else. You can't use a word like that around me without it carrying all kinds of connotations. One of which in, you know, the religious tradition is simply the whole question of the difference in God's relationship to man between the old covenant and the new covenant. The term covenant is used to refer to a relationship or a deal between God and man. One of the things you'll notice in the first trilogy is that Covenants always trying to make deals with the land. I'll do this if you'll do that, or if you don't ask me to do this, I won't ask you to do that sort of thing. Every deal that he makes seduces him a step further, but they always fail because he's using them as substitutes for real commitment. In a biblical tradition, the first covenant, the old covenant, was the covenant of law in which God gives you a bunch of rules to live by and if you live by those rules, you're going to go to heaven and everybody will be happy. As opposed to the new covenant, the Christ covenant, which is the covenant of grace where essentially it says, you know, okay, we found out you can't live by the rules after all, but I still want to give you some way to get to heaven, you know, so we'll have this sacrificial kind of act, and, you know, I'll send my son to die for your sins, and you can be forgiven for not living according to the rules. And that brings up the question of law in relation to man, and what law can mean. And, of course, particularly in the first trilogy, law is a very important concept for the lords. They mean something different than a set of rules. But in a way, it is a set of rules. For them, law is the way nature works, and you have to live your life in service to the way nature works and in harmony with the way nature works. And if you become a corruptive or destructive influence, then you're going against law. So, I mean, the thematic implications run in all kinds of directions. The same thing is true, of course, for the name Thomas. Thomas was the disciple of Christ who doubted Christ's resurrection, who doubted the fundamental religious idea on which 2,000 years Christian history was going to be built." Well, Covenant, Thomas Covenant, my character, is a doubter of a certain kind of sin. He takes the really key point and rejects it for a while. And that allows me to imply various sorts of religious implications, which I like working with. Throughout all the books, you have references, of course, to this long background, people like Barry Caffhand and Kevin Landwaster and the ritual of desecration, things that occurred well in the past. Is this a scheme that you've worked out, say, like in the manner of Tolkien, a whole scheme and you're just telling one little portion of it? Not in the manner of Tolkien. Tolkien really did work out a grand scheme, and a lot of it he worked out before he ever decided to write Lord of the Rings or The Hobbit. this was his hobby, in a sense, was evolving this history of the elves in the world, of which Middle-earth is only a small part. And eventually he got attracted to the idea of taking a small portion of this entire world history and trying to write it down for other people to read to see if they would enjoy it. Not so for me. I started with the climax of the power, of the Preserves. And I evolved everything else to try to aim toward that end. So for me, people like Kevin and Beric and everything else were things that I made up to set up the issues that I wanted to focus in on in The Power of the Preserves. This is one reason that I can't write spinoff stories or secondary tales. You'll never hear a short story from me about what some giant did over somewhere else or the adventures of so-and-so hidden over here, my brain doesn't work that way. I only made this stuff up because it goes to that focal point that I'm aiming at, the climax of the power that preserves, and the stuff that I made up fits that. It serves the purpose for which I intended it, but in my mind, it doesn't have a life of its own, the way Tolkien's whole history background had a life of its own. And so I just, I mean, they'll never be the Donaldson equivalent of a Silmarillian because I haven't created any of that kind of material, and I'm not likely to. I imagine a lot of your readers' idea have probably responded to the Giants very positively. Excuse me. That's okay. We'll edit those out. Good. I guess I don't want to phrase this. Where did you get the giants from? I mean, in mythology and a legend, usually bad guys. Well, I knew that, so when I was originally planning the story, I wanted to reverse that and to have giants who are good guys. But that was as far as it went. In any creative project of this size, there are some things that you can track down and explain very clearly and that there's other things that seem to happen by serendipity. There's an element of discovery in any creative act. You discover your own material, and that's balanced off by lots of other kinds of things that you do. I knew that I needed characters in the story. I was going to call them giants. They were going to do this and that. I knew what their function was going to be in the story. I knew what was going to happen. I knew names for them. But the fact is that when I started writing Lord Files Bane, I didn't have any idea what their personality was like. I just hadn't figured that out. So my method in writing is very subjective. Essentially, I start looking at everything through the eyes of my characters, and I just try to see what they see and feel what they're feeling. It's a self-hypnosis kind of writing where we try to eliminate Steve Donelson from existence, and the page ties right into whatever the ideas are and I just try to write. Of course that means I have to do a lot of rewriting later. But at the time, it's very subjective, it's very experiential. And me, Covenant, and Elena were standing on the banks of the Salzees when I first met a giant. You know, this boat was coming sailing up the river and I'm just sitting there at the typewriter watching the boat come up the river. And I saw, you know, I mean, I knew it was gonna be a giant on board. As the author, I had that one advantage over at Covenant L.A. and I knew I was going to be a giant on board. But I was just typing along and I think, oh, so this is what he looks like. And I'm starting to, you know, just typing away. I'm just seeing him come up the river. It's like he's coming up the river that's being projected on a screen on the edge of the type desk or something. It was a real discovery for me. I found out what he's, before he started to talk and I think, oh, you know, this is kind of a nice guy, you know. And I started getting, oh, into storytelling and all this. Oh, boy, I love these giants. This is great stuff. I didn't premeditate any of that. It was a real discovery for me and a very happy discovery. I had a wonderful time meeting giants for the first time. And that, of course, shaped the whole context of finding out about their personality, really cast a lot of light over all the things that they were then going to do in the story. And there were some things that I had worked out that I was going to have happen in the story, which at the time seemed purely mechanical. For example, this question of the destruction of the unhomed in Sea Reach that takes place in the Ill-Earth War, where a raver goes and essentially knocks off all the living giants. excuse me now I planned that for purely practical reasons I knew that if I were Lord Fowl and I really wanted to march out there with my armies and defeat the Lords the one thing I could never do would be to leave a party of giants sitting behind me to attack me from the rear just when I thought I had the giants where I wanted them I mean the Lords where I wanted them it's just craziness the giants are over here the Lords are over there and if I go fight the Lords these giants are just going to come plowing into me and I'm never going to be safe. The only good way to attack the Lords is to take care of the Giants first, and I just knew that Fowl was going to do that. That's a perfectly logical thing. He is going to do something about those Giants and he's going to make it so that they can't fight. But that's a very mechanical kind of storytelling decision, and it's years away. Actually, from my point of view, I'm still writing Lord Fowl's Bane. That's coming up in the future. When I meet Saul Heart, phone follower, and start to find out what giants are really like, this suddenly then becomes a very important and also painful part of the story because suddenly, you know, I fall in love with this entire race of people and I realize, ah, down the line, I'm going to have them all killed off. It becomes, it becomes emotionally central to the whole, to the whole story. It becomes one of the really difficult things that all of the characters have to deal with. and that, you know, that discovery of Foam Follower coming up the river just sheds light and implications down the whole path of the story and to things that I could never have foreseen. Okay, I know the answer to this, but let me ask anyhow. You had always intended from the moment you started, you had this image of the end of The Power that Preserves the Ending that you started writing. You had the idea of writing six books, two trilogies. No, well, I started with the ending of The Power that Preserves. That's three books. What happened was that as I was finishing working on The Power that Preserves, I became... Dissatisfied isn't the right word. I think the first trilogy is perfectly authentic and satisfactory on its own terms. But I became aware that evil is a much more complicated question than that. Essentially, what happens in The First Chronicles of Thomas' Covenant is the Hitler situation. Hitler comes along, he raises a big army, he wants to conquer the world. The only thing you can do is to raise a big army yourself and try and stop him. And it turns out whoever can put out the best muscle in the field is going to be the one who wins. Now, as it happens in the case of Hitler, the good guys won. And as it happens in the case of the Chronicles of Thomas' Covenant, the good guys win. But just because you have more muscle doesn't make you the good guy or the bad guy. It's just muscle. and on a certain level that's a fairly simple-minded kind of kind of thing evil comes in many different guises um and not all of them are that clear or that obvious and in a lot of the cases muscle doesn't have anything to do with it muscle isn't going to do us any good when we got richard nixon for president because the kind of unscrupulous thing that richard nixon is doing is something to which muscle is an inappropriate response you know they just don't connect and when Lord Fowle does things other than field armies muscle is not the answer well I got to thinking about things like that while I was finishing work on the power that preserves and got another hot flash for what then became the ending of White Gold Wielder for what would happen well if evil doesn't do that what would it do and how would it work and I got this really exciting kind of vision of of the climax of the power that preserves and then i was back where i was before where i had to plan backward to uh to figure out what the whole situation had been and how it had come about okay um i also know the answer to this because i've heard your speeches but i still it's possible for you to give a brief answer um one of the people that asked you a question i forget which section it was that uh at the end of the first trilogy you give us hope the good guys win. And here we have the second one, and all of a sudden that's not fair. Evil's still there, we didn't win after all. At the end of the first trilogy you'd give us hope, but then you'd start all over again and take it away from us. Why? Well, for one thing, if evil has been defeated, what are you going to do for a second trilogy? I mean, from a perfectly practical point of view, some of these things are necessary. But there are lots of different answers, and one of them is just a matter of perspective. This whole time differential thing that occurs between covenant's world and the land, much, much, much, much more time is passing in the land than is passing in covenant's life. And for the land, it's been three and a half thousand years. Now, how big a victory does it have to be? The fact is that nothing in life is absolutely permanent. And Covenant's previous victory provided 2,000 years of peace and happiness. You know, we can't get 15 years out of World War II. You know, we go through all of that. And by, you know, oh, six years later, we're in Korea. And, you know, what, 12 years after that, we're in Vietnam. You know, for us, when we win in the real world, when we win a victory, You know, it lasts for minutes. Covenant's victory lasted a long time. It is just not reasonable that that would last forever. In addition to that, I tried to make it clear in the first trilogy that Covenant was not killing Lord Fowl. You can't kill despite, because in the final analysis, despite is part of what it means to be human. And you can't exterminate your own personality. What he does is masters it, in a sense, in the first trilogy. defuses it for a while and you don't like taking the venom out of snake fangs or something like that it be you know life becomes safe for a while but it's just as sure as death and taxes you know this stuff is going to going to grow back and it seems perfectly reasonable of course from a reader's point of view you know covenant it's 10 years for a reader's point of view it may very well have been five minutes since they finished reading the power that preserves they pick up the wounded land and they find everything's going to hell in a handbasket Essentially, what I've done is I've nuked the land, you know, so I can understand that for a reader, this can be a real shock. You have this victory at the end of the power that preserves. And it's not, in some ways, it's not a very dramatic victory. Now, what I mean is that there's not a lot of emotional fanfare attached to the victory. You know, they don't have ticker tape parades. You know, they don't spend the way they do in Lord of the Rings. They don't spend 50 pages explaining what happened to everybody after the victory. They don't, you know. Covenant doesn't go back to Lord Morham and they don't fall on each other's arms and shake hands and give in a feast and drink a bunch of toasts and all this other kind of stuff. There's not a lot of validation. Covenant wins. The land is safe. That's the end of the story. You know, Covenant wakes up in the hospital bed and smiles and decides it's okay to go on living. And then you go from there bingo, bango. And, you know, from fictional terms, it's 10 years. from the reader's point of view, it's five minutes and everything's been destroyed. You know, that's tough. And I appreciate the position that puts a reader in. But you have to realize that from my position, it's a very natural storytelling development. And without it, there wouldn't be a story for me to tell. Okay, listen, how are we doing on time? I could talk for hours on this and I don't want to take too much of your time, are we? Well, that's pretty much up to you all. I can go on for another 10 or 15 minutes anyway. I need it if you could. Okay. Yeah, okay. Thank you. The choice of white gold. I think it was in the one tree. Maybe it was set elsewhere. One of the characters says that white gold exists only in Covenant's Ring. That it's an unnatural alliance of metals. Why did you choose that? Well, precisely because it is an alliance of metals. You're never going to find white gold ore. I don't care what world it is. It's an alloy. white, people make white gold. It doesn't occur. And that makes it possible for me to hypothesize a world in which that particular technology does not exist. There's no gold at all in the first trilogy, but you do find in the second, if you travel around the world, that there are other cultures with different attitudes who have discovered gold. Yellow gold. The Kemper in Brothero uses gold as a magical thing. So the metals do physically exist on the planet, but it is a particular kind of alloy, and that makes it—I can then plausibly claim that this alloy does not exist in that world. Now, that's from a pragmatic point of view. From a thematic point of view, it's really important that we're talking about something here that is a combination of materials. The wedding ring that Covenant carries is, like himself, a paradox of a certain sense, or symbolically a paradox. It is made out of disparate materials. It is one kind of metal and another kind of metal fused together, and that is what Covenant does essentially in the course of the story, is that he learns to fuse the disparate sides of his dilemma, what they call the impossibility of believing the land true and the impossibility of believing it false, and he finds a way to make those into one thing. And it is out of those kinds of paradoxes that his strength comes, and so, of course, a ring that is an alloy is symbolically apt for those sorts of issues. That's what I want to guess. Okay, I think I read this correctly, but I would like to ask you about it. Of course, the staff of law is one of the more important devices, motifs. But you have it destroyed in the first trilogy. Okay, at the end of the second trilogy, it's reforged in a sense. You have the appointed, is that the Elohim? he appointed in vain. Okay, did I read this correctly in that the appoint or the elohim, they're sort of the matter of the earth, the essence of it. Vain is the structure. Well, energy and structure. That's the simple way to put it. Um, any any principle of power, I think, has to have energy and structure. William Blake used to talk about this. Reason is the circumference of energy. And if you don't have both reason and energy, you don't have anything at all. Because if reason doesn't restrict energy, then it just floats away and you don't have any energy. And if energy doesn't press against reason, then, you know, it's like a balloon. There's nothing happening. Reason is lying there dead. And I think it seems natural to me that it would be that way in any situation. You need structure or rules, balance, order, and you need energy which is contained within that in order for there to be any effectiveness. And this, of course, is perfectly consistent with the whole concept of law that's posited throughout the first and second trilogies. In this particular case, there is one other element that goes into remaking a staff of law, and that is the element of intention, which Lyndon Avery provides. but she provides the sense of purpose for the melding, but without the perfect structure which the er vials created when they made Vain, and without this totally unstructured kind of energy which the Elohim represent, you know, it wouldn't be possible to remake the staff of law. And after all, it's not just an ordinary tool of magic we're talking about here. but it's explained over and over again throughout the series that the staff of law, by its very nature, supports and defends the natural order. And it's very hard to use the power that the staff represents to do anything which violates the natural order or natural law. And when the staff is broken, that inherently weakens the entire natural order. It's more than just a magical tool here. It's an expression of a certain aspect of the existence of this world. And to make something like that again requires an extraordinary combination of potentialities and purposes. Is that second step going to be stronger than the first? Well, I think it's going to be different in some ways. I wouldn't want to say stronger or something. But in the back of my mind, for example, I think of it as a living staff rather than as a piece of wood which is being used. Because, I mean, after all, Vane and Findale both went in to make that. And it would not – I mean, I don't know everything that's going to happen in the future. I haven't tried to figure it out. But it would not surprise me to find that this staff had a mind of its own. if it comes back in future stories and that there are various ways in which dealing with it is very different than with the old staff flaw. Okay, I know when you go to conventions and you talk to fans and they ask about your books and so forth, I'm sure they ask you about your style and the use of your vocabulary, your large vocabulary and so forth. I heard you say this yesterday, but I have sensed this myself, I hope even before I heard you say it. You must have fun with your choice of words. Yeah, fun not in any – I'm sure there are people who think that I have fun in the sense of, boy, I'm going to fool people with this word. Ha, ha, ha, those stupid readers, they'll never know what I'm talking about now. That's not it at all. I really am not trying to confuse the issue by the vocabulary that I use. It is intended to communicate, and generally I find that readers who do the work to figure out what these words mean find that it does communicate, that it says what I mean, and there are plenty of circumstances where I can justify that even though the word is unfamiliar or maybe even unknown to people, it's actually more precise than the other choices that I have. but the thing that gets me involved in that in the first place is that is that just words themselves seem to me to be a happy thing, I love words, I get a great sense of pleasure out of discovering a word that I didn't know before and finding out what it means and finding out how it can be used, you know, that cheers me up and there are lots of ways in which I think that if my readers could just hear those words in the spirit in which I put them in the prose, they would find, for example, that the covenant books aren't as grim in mood as they think they are. Because I'm shooting out these little gleams of pleasure all the time. and I wish those could be received in the way they were meant because then people would, well, like real Musgrave, you were at the panel yesterday, real is an interesting man and there are times when he just laughs and chuckles and grins reading things in my books which are grim and he knows that they're grim, it's not like he's stupid or insensitive but he's also picking up some of the other things that I'm trying to project as well There is an element of joy in those books which balances a lot of the dismay. And from my point of view, unfortunately, it's conveyed in, it's like being conveyed in code. It's conveyed through my love of language, and not everybody on the other end receives that message that I'm trying to put out.

segments.text: Just a brief statement on how you became a professional writer, the background that led you to it
Well it's, you know, everybody's story is a long story
It's much easier for other people to summarize you than it is for you to summarize yourself
I conceived in college the ambition to be a professional writer of fiction
It was a number of years before I stumbled into writing fantasy
and that was a crucial
thing for me because my writing got a great deal better when I started to write fantasy
but that had been about 8 years
I had been writing as hard as I knew how for 8 years before I started
on fantasy and from the time I started writing fantasy until I
finally achieved a publication of some kind was another 5 years
so I had a
a 13-year apprenticeship
in a sense and then it's been
only since then that I've been able to support
myself as a writer.
Did you grow up reading science fiction?
Well, actually no.
And not for any other reason
than in terms of what I call a historical
accident. I was living
in India because my parents were medical missionaries
to India and we simply got
a very erratic supply of books.
There was no one particular kind of
thing that we got except
mystery novels. Missionaries love to read mystery novels. I don't know quite why that is.
But other than that, it was a random sampling of everything. I read Leon Urus and the Hardy
Boys at the same time, and I read Bamba the Jungle Boy, and I read James Michener, and
a whole range of things, whatever I could get my hands on.
Now, I loved every science fiction novel that I got my hands on, of which I can remember every one.
There were three. I read three by the time I was a high school graduate. One was Alfred Bester's
The Star Is My Destination. One was A.J. Boudry's Rogue Moon. And one was Theodore Sturgeon's More
Than Human. Now, it's just an accident that I happened to get to read three classics in the
only three science fiction books I read. They made a great impression on me, but that was all there
was. Now, I came to the United States at the end of my high school days to start college,
and I wanted to read more science fiction, but I didn't know any people who read it. So I didn't
know any place to get information about what was worth reading. And what I would do is wander
into a drugstore and pick up a science fiction book. And you can get some remarkably bad books
doing that. And the things that I picked up in the first couple of years in drugstores were so
terrible that I stopped reading science fiction. And in fact, I didn't start reading science fiction
again until I was finally in a position where I knew people who could make recommendations
to separate out the real garbage from the good stuff.
Were the Chronicles of Thomas' Covenant, the first Chronicles, was that your first published work?
Yes. Well, actually, I had a couple of letters to the editor published in the Avengers comic books back in the late 60s, but that was the only other time my name was in print.
I heard you talk about this, I think it was yesterday. You did have a lot of trouble getting that accepted.
I had a great deal of trouble getting my break.
Lord Filesbane was rejected by every fiction publisher in the United States
and also by all the magazines that did serializations at that time
and also by several agents.
By the time I had finished having that book rejected,
it had been rejected 47 times.
It took three and a half years or so for me to do that.
It was a very difficult process.
And in a lot of ways, I was saved.
by happenstance. After being, I went through the alphabet from A to Z with publishers,
and when I got to Z, I didn't know what else to do. I thought that it might work if I tried
to send my book to British publishers. I mean, I didn't have anywhere else to turn at that
point. So I sent away for a directory of British publishing so that I could begin going from
A to Z in England. And while I was waiting for that book to come, I just couldn't bear
to let my manuscript sit. So I resubmitted it to Ballantyne Books. And the only reason I did that
was because they published Lord of the Rings, which meant to me that they were a profitable
company. If they were making some money, there's at least a slightly better chance that they'd
take a wing on somebody like me. What I did not know was that since the last time I had
submitted my book to Ballantyne they had fired their entire editorial staff and
had all the new people and essentially what they had was Lester and Judy Lynn
Del Rey and the delrays jumped on Lord Falls Bay as soon as they got it they
knew almost immediately that they wanted to publish this material changed my life
but up until then it was an extremely difficult process
this was unfair question I'm sure it's too general to be really fair one but
was there a particular impetus behind that novel?
Well, that is pretty gentle.
I don't know what kind of impetus you're talking about.
When you started to write, was there something in your mind that said,
I want to write a novel of this type about Thomas Covenant, who's a leper and so forth?
Well, the key thing for me about The Chronicles of Thomas Covenant
was that my inspiration for it came from the end.
The first idea that occurred for me for that book was for the climax of The Power That Preserves.
Now, when I got a story going, I had an entire story ready to tell.
And from that point of view, the impetus that got me going on Lord Files Bane was the climax
of The Power That Preserves.
And that has been my pattern in all the Covenant books is that I have worked them all backwards.
I mean, I don't write them backwards, but I plan them and arrange them backwards.
The thing that inspires me to write the story comes at the end.
So with the second Chronicles, it was the climax of White Gold Wielder that convinced me that I wanted to write a second Chronicles.
And essentially, my method is that I have this climactic scene in mind, and I have to answer the simple questions like, who are these guys and how did they get into this mess?
And I plan backwards on that basis.
Well, in order for that to happen, these things must have happened first.
And if those things must have happened first, then these kinds of people must have been
doing those kinds of things.
And I arrange everything backwards until I get to a point where I can start writing,
which means that the one thing that's absolutely clear to me the whole time when I'm working
on these things, I know where I'm going.
I know exactly what the purpose of all these events is.
It's going to produce that result, which you as a reader will finally come to at the end of 1,500 pages or whatever.
And in the case of the first Chronicles, it was that climactic scene where Thomas Covenant, who has been rejecting the importance of his fantasy experience, comes face to face with Lord Fowle.
And the fact that he disbelieves in some way in the reality of the fantasy gives him the emotional power to not be crushed by Lord Phowel.
He knows he doesn't need to be overwhelmed by evil because he denies its external reality.
I mean, he knows there's evil in him,
but he doesn't have to be overwhelmed by this externalization of evil.
And that makes it possible for him to win.
Well, I knew that was where I was going the entire time I worked on the first trilogy.
Okay.
I think in one of your glossaries at the end of one of the books,
you had the land, you had it defined as a focal region of the Earth.
Yeah.
You didn't have a particular spot or a where that the land is supposed to be located then.
Well, I know it's on a globe.
You know, I mean, this is a world, and the land is only,
obviously it's only a small continental portion of an entire world.
When you get into the second chronicles of Thomas' Covenant
and people start voyaging around,
you at least get some sense that there are lots of other things going on in the world too.
My perception of it is that the land is kind of like the arena in which the crucial issues for the whole world are fought out.
And although they have implications and ramifications which affect events in other parts of the world
and different things happen maybe because of what's happening in the land, but that everything focuses there.
Now this is, you know, it's a subtle question in some ways, and it's crucial in others.
In the One Tree, the characters, the Elohim, who consider themselves to be very godlike, if not God itself,
one problem for them is that the crucial events are happening somewhere else.
And they think, I mean, obviously since we're crucial, if what's happening to you were really important,
it would have been happening here instead of way over there.
and that leads them into some decisions of questionable ethics.
But for the thrust of the Covenant books as a whole,
it's certainly true that the land is where the main battles are being fought
and other stuff feeds into that but is not central.
Hey, Covenant, at least in my experience with fantasy,
I imagine for a lot of readers too, Covenant is sort of an anti-hero.
You know, being a leper for one reason,
but also being a, doesn't want to be a hero in the first place.
Why pick somebody that was not in the traditional?
Well, for one thing, you know, I mean, I wasn't aware of the tradition.
I had read Lord of the Rings,
but other than that I hadn't read much fantasy myself.
So I wasn't making a conscious decision to go for or against anything normal.
I was just trying to deal with something that seemed to me
to be exciting and appropriate.
Now, for me,
the story started with
the climax of the power that preserves.
I have an unbeliever confronting
the evil principle
and rising above it.
Well, I had that idea
in my head for like three years before I ever had,
before I could figure out
who those guys were and how they got into that mess.
That original idea,
although it was very powerful to me, was also static.
There was no story attached.

I got a story when it occurred to me that the person who was going to go from the real world to the fantasy world and reject the fantasy world in favor of the real world should be somebody whose real world is unbearable and whose fantasy world is terrific.
I mean, look at it the other way around.
Suppose you have a terrific real life.
And you have these rotten fantasies.
if you then say I don't care about the fantasy I'm going to stick with reality what does that mean
you know I mean you just that's normal self-interest anybody anybody who has a terrible
time in their nightmares and a wonderful time in the rest of their life is going to prefer the
rest of their life it only becomes a moral statement when you have somebody who really
hates their life because their life is terrible
and their dreams are just wonderful and they still say, I'm going to reject the dream because
I know the difference and even though reality is terrible, I'm going to still affirm reality.
Now that, you know, may seem a little unbalanced or crazy to some people, but it is a moral
statement of some kind because there's no self-interest in it. It's not something that
you do to make yourself feel better. It's something that you do as an ideal or as a belief,
a religious belief.
And, of course, whose real life could be lousier than a leper's.
Now, as soon as I thought of that, then I had a story.
I had a fantasy world, because all I had to do was invent a fantasy world
that is the direct opposite of being a leper.
And I had, you know, everything fell into place for me
as soon as I thought of that kind of thing.
Now, I never intended that as an anti-hero kind of situation.
From my point of view, the only thing that makes Covenant an antihero
is that he doesn't want to be a hero.
He's afraid of being a hero.
But he is a hero.
From my point of view.
And I think most of my readers eventually get sucked into the point,
even though they don't like him in the beginning.
First they start to admit that he's got some reasons for what he does
and then they start grudgingly to respect what he's doing.
And before you know it, people end up liking him and identifying with him
as if he were a normal hero.
and that's certainly the way it is for me
I cared a lot about this character
from the very beginning
and I never worked with him
as something that I would call anti-anything
I knew he was having a tough time
I knew it was rotten to be in the position
that he was in
and I knew from various kinds of studies and research
what sorts of psychological problems
people who suffer from leprosy develop
what does it feel like
to be despised by everybody around you
for something that has nothing to do
with what you did or didn't do.
You just got this disease, you don't know why,
everybody hates you.
That exerts a tremendous psychological stress
and it doesn't make people beautiful.
You don't become a nice guy
just because you got leprosy.
The pressure brings, any kind of pressure,
brings out the flaws in human nature.
That's where you find out
that there are areas where you're weak
and there are areas where you're not very graceful
is when somebody puts a lot of pressure on you and you start to get a little nasty
and you start to get a little impatient and you start to do this and start to do that.
It seemed obvious to me, particularly at the beginning,
that Koffman is under tremendous kinds of psychological and emotional pressure
and he's not going to be a very likable guy.
But what's going to happen, and of course I knew this all along,
what's going to happen is that in the course of coping with this dilemma,
he was going to essentially reintegrate his whole personality
and become a constructive individual who does know what he cares about
and who does love other people and who is willing to fight for that.
So from my point of view, there was never any identification problem.
I identified with him a lot from the beginning.
For a reader, it's different.
A reader doesn't know where I'm going.
And so they have to kind of evaluate things as it goes along.
And for many readers, in the beginning, covenant is just very obnoxious.
then later they learn to kind of understand him a bit.
I guess
to me, one of the paradoxes
I guess it's a paradox that all six volumes
is based upon is the idea that
Covenant's power, his ability to combat
despite Lord Fowl, is simply the fact
that he is a leper and does have such a
I guess a lousy life in the real world.
That gives him a strength.
Yeah, it gives him an emotional strength.
what passes for magic in the Covenant books really is just an external expression of personality.
The strength for magic always comes from inside the individual in this kind of world.
And what creates emotional strength is what makes magic.
like Lord Morum, who it becomes in the first Chronicles becomes the strongest of the lords,
really, and does something that nobody else has been able to do in the end when he when
he kills the giant raver that's attacking them.
You know, what's really an issue for there is emotional strength.
It's not it's not that you that you know more than somebody else does you know more
spells than somebody else does or you've studied a different book of Arcana and have
learned different kinds of magic or anything else.
In this kind of world, magic doesn't hinge on that sort of thing.
It hinges on the strengths and weaknesses of your own personality.
And that's where the danger comes from of course because people who have that susceptibility
to pressure to where like Kevin, they crack when things get too bad.
Then they fall into despair and you get the same people who perform the ritual of desecration.
The key issue is the personality of the person who has the power.
or their personality structure, how strong or how weak they are.
And what Covenant becomes over the course of these six books
is this incredibly strong personality.
And eventually, he becomes such a strong personality
that in certain ways he doesn't need magic anymore.
You'll find this when you've read through to the end of White Gold Wilder,
That he dominates situations without using magic anymore because he has become such a strong structure internally, emotionally.
i imagine um one of the joys of being a fantasy writer is in naming things i've always been
impressed with your your the way you pick names for things and i wondered if that was something
that comes naturally to you or you work at it or well i'm always a little embarrassed because
traditionally um i mean if you assume that the tradition is tolkien then there's really a
background for names
certainly in Tolkien as he evolved an entire language of Elvish
and worked out immensely elaborate structures which backup the names
I have never been able to do that
As a matter of fact I have trouble with foreign languages of any kind
and became that close to flunking college German and stuff
I do it by ear
it's a very much intuitive kind of process for me
Now, there are situations in which I beg, borrow, or steal words that mean something that I use for names.
Like, for example, all the names of the ravers are words that have meaning.
And I use those words because they mean something, but also because those words have the right sound to my ear for what I want.
So in those situations, the name has to meet two criteria.
The meaning has to be appropriate, and it still has to sound right.
Other than that, I do it by sound.
Certain kinds of combinations of sounds and whatnot sound good and strong and positive to me.
And they sound like good guys.
And other combinations of sounds sound like bad guys.
You know, I make it up.
I try to make it up consistently, obviously.
Now, for example, all the giants have names which are combinations of normal words.
Salt, heart, foam, follower.
You know, those are all English words and you just string them together.
So obviously when I'm making up names for my characters, I'm not going to make up that kind of name for one giant
and then make up a completely different nonsense syllable kind of name for another giant.
All the giants have the same kind of names.
As it happens, the ramen, the people in the first trilogy who work with the horses,
they all have names based on Indian words that I knew when I was a kid growing up in Indian.
I just needed some sort of principle to help me pull it together so that I'm sure I'd be consistent about that name.
So all those people have names that are based on Indian words.
the bloodguard and the hiru-chai all have
names of certain, sometimes they have two syllables more often than not
they're one syllable words, you know, brin, kale, kier
you know, and they're all words that seem to me to
they're full of consonants, they're fairly strong sounding, but they're not words that
that would carry any direct meaning in English
you know, so I follow patterns, but I am doing it
doing it by ear.
I would imagine too that the name covenant
has meaning, doesn't it?
Oh, well, of course.
You know, I have my religious background
and everything else.
You can't use a word like that around me
without it carrying all kinds of connotations.
One of which in, you know,
the religious tradition is simply
the whole question of the difference
in God's relationship to man
between the old covenant and the new covenant.
The term covenant is used to refer to
a relationship or a deal between God and man. One of the things you'll notice in the first
trilogy is that Covenants always trying to make deals with the land. I'll do this if you'll do
that, or if you don't ask me to do this, I won't ask you to do that sort of thing.
Every deal that he makes seduces him a step further, but they always fail because
he's using them as substitutes for real commitment. In a biblical tradition,
the first covenant, the old covenant, was the covenant of law in which God gives you a bunch
of rules to live by and if you live by those rules, you're going to go to heaven and everybody
will be happy. As opposed to the new covenant, the Christ covenant, which is the covenant of grace
where essentially it says, you know, okay, we found out you can't live by the rules after all,
but I still want to give you some way to get to heaven, you know, so we'll have this sacrificial
kind of act, and, you know, I'll send my son to die for your sins, and you can be forgiven for
not living according to the rules. And that brings up the question of law in relation to man,
and what law can mean. And, of course, particularly in the first trilogy, law is a very important
concept for the lords. They mean something different than a set of rules. But in a way,
it is a set of rules. For them, law is the way nature works, and you have to live your life
in service to the way nature works
and in harmony
with the way nature works.
And if you become a corruptive
or destructive influence,
then you're going against law.
So, I mean,
the thematic implications
run in all kinds of directions.
The same thing is true, of course,
for the name Thomas.
Thomas was the disciple of Christ
who doubted Christ's resurrection,
who doubted the fundamental
religious idea
on which 2,000 years
Christian history was going to be built."
Well, Covenant, Thomas Covenant, my character, is a doubter of a certain kind of sin.
He takes the really key point and rejects it for a while.
And that allows me to imply various sorts of religious implications,
which I like working with.
Throughout all the books, you have references, of course, to this long background,
people like Barry Caffhand and Kevin Landwaster and the ritual of desecration,
things that occurred well in the past.
Is this a scheme that you've worked out, say, like in the manner of Tolkien,
a whole scheme and you're just telling one little portion of it?
Not in the manner of Tolkien.
Tolkien really did work out a grand scheme,
and a lot of it he worked out before he ever decided to write Lord of the Rings or The Hobbit.
this was his hobby, in a sense,
was evolving this history of the elves in the world,
of which Middle-earth is only a small part.
And eventually he got attracted to the idea
of taking a small portion of this entire world history
and trying to write it down for other people to read
to see if they would enjoy it.
Not so for me.
I started with the climax of the power,
of the Preserves. And I evolved everything else to try to aim toward that end. So for me, people
like Kevin and Beric and everything else were things that I made up to set up the issues that
I wanted to focus in on in The Power of the Preserves. This is one reason that I can't write
spinoff stories or secondary tales. You'll never hear a short story from me about what some giant
did over somewhere else or the adventures of so-and-so hidden over here, my brain doesn't
work that way.
I only made this stuff up because it goes to that focal point that I'm aiming at, the
climax of the power that preserves, and the stuff that I made up fits that.
It serves the purpose for which I intended it, but in my mind, it doesn't have a life
of its own, the way Tolkien's whole history background had a life of its own.
And so I just, I mean, they'll never be the Donaldson equivalent of a Silmarillian
because I haven't created any of that kind of material, and I'm not likely to.
I imagine a lot of your readers' idea have probably responded to the Giants very positively.
Excuse me.
That's okay. We'll edit those out.
Good.
I guess I don't want to phrase this.
Where did you get the giants from?
I mean, in mythology and a legend, usually bad guys.
Well, I knew that, so when I was originally planning the story,
I wanted to reverse that and to have giants who are good guys.
But that was as far as it went.
In any creative project of this size,
there are some things that you can track down and explain very clearly
and that there's other things that seem to happen by serendipity.
There's an element of discovery in any creative act.
You discover your own material, and that's balanced off by lots of other kinds of things that you do.
I knew that I needed characters in the story.
I was going to call them giants.
They were going to do this and that.
I knew what their function was going to be in the story.
I knew what was going to happen.
I knew names for them.
But the fact is that when I started writing Lord Files Bane,
I didn't have any idea what their personality was like.
I just hadn't figured that out.
So my method in writing is very subjective.
Essentially, I start looking at everything through the eyes of my characters,
and I just try to see what they see and feel what they're feeling.
It's a self-hypnosis kind of writing where we try to eliminate Steve Donelson from existence,
and the page ties right into whatever the ideas are
and I just try to write.
Of course that means I have to do a lot of rewriting later.
But at the time, it's very subjective,

The choice of white gold.
I think it was in the one tree.
Maybe it was set elsewhere.
One of the characters says that white gold exists only in Covenant's Ring.
That it's an unnatural alliance of metals.
Why did you choose that?
Well, precisely because it is an alliance of metals.
You're never going to find white gold ore.
I don't care what world it is.
It's an alloy.
white, people make white gold. It doesn't occur. And that makes it possible for me to
hypothesize a world in which that particular technology does not exist. There's no gold
at all in the first trilogy, but you do find in the second, if you travel around the world,
that there are other cultures with different attitudes who have discovered gold. Yellow
gold. The Kemper in Brothero uses gold as a magical thing. So the metals do physically
exist on the planet, but it is a particular kind of alloy, and that makes it—I can then
plausibly claim that this alloy does not exist in that world.
Now, that's from a pragmatic point of view.
From a thematic point of view, it's really important that we're talking about something
here that is a combination of materials.
The wedding ring that Covenant carries is, like himself, a paradox of a certain sense,
or symbolically a paradox.
It is made out of disparate materials.
It is one kind of metal and another kind of metal fused together,
and that is what Covenant does essentially in the course of the story,
is that he learns to fuse the disparate sides of his dilemma,
what they call the impossibility of believing the land true
and the impossibility of believing it false,
and he finds a way to make those into one thing.
And it is out of those kinds of paradoxes that his strength comes,
and so, of course, a ring that is an alloy is symbolically apt for those sorts of issues.
That's what I want to guess.

he appointed in vain.

appoint or the elohim, they're sort of
the matter of the earth, the essence of it.

Well, energy and structure.

way to put it.
Um,
any
any principle
of power, I think,
has to have
energy and structure.
William Blake used to talk about this.
Reason is the circumference of energy.
And if you don't have both reason and energy, you don't have anything at all.
Because if reason doesn't restrict energy, then it just floats away and you don't have any energy.
And if energy doesn't press against reason, then, you know, it's like a balloon.
There's nothing happening.
Reason is lying there dead.
And I think it seems natural to me that it would be that way in any situation.
You need structure or rules, balance, order, and you need energy which is contained within that in order for there to be any effectiveness.
And this, of course, is perfectly consistent with the whole concept of law that's posited throughout the first and second trilogies.
In this particular case, there is one other element that goes into remaking a staff of law, and that is the element of intention, which Lyndon Avery provides.
but she provides the sense of purpose for the melding, but without the perfect structure
which the er vials created when they made Vain, and without this totally unstructured
kind of energy which the Elohim represent, you know, it wouldn't be possible to remake
the staff of law.
And after all, it's not just an ordinary tool of magic we're talking about here.
but it's explained over and over again throughout the series that the staff of law, by its very nature, supports and defends the natural order.
And it's very hard to use the power that the staff represents to do anything which violates the natural order or natural law.
And when the staff is broken, that inherently weakens the entire natural order.
It's more than just a magical tool here.
It's an expression of a certain aspect of the existence of this world.
And to make something like that again requires an extraordinary combination of potentialities and purposes.
Is that second step going to be stronger than the first?
Well, I think it's going to be different in some ways.
I wouldn't want to say stronger or something.
But in the back of my mind, for example, I think of it as a living staff rather than as a piece of wood which is being used.
Because, I mean, after all, Vane and Findale both went in to make that.
And it would not – I mean, I don't know everything that's going to happen in the future.
I haven't tried to figure it out.

if it comes back in future stories
and that there are various ways in which dealing with it

Okay, I know when you go to conventions
and you talk to fans
and they ask about your books and so forth,
I'm sure they ask you about your style
and the use of your vocabulary,
your large vocabulary and so forth.
I heard you say this yesterday,
but I have sensed this myself,
I hope even before I heard you say it.
You must have fun with your choice of words.
Yeah, fun not in any – I'm sure there are people who think that I have fun in the sense
of, boy, I'm going to fool people with this word.
Ha, ha, ha, those stupid readers, they'll never know what I'm talking about now.
That's not it at all.
I really am not trying to confuse the issue by the vocabulary that I use.
It is intended to communicate, and generally I find that readers who do the work to figure
out what these words mean find that it does communicate, that it says what I mean, and
there are plenty of circumstances where I can justify that even though the word is unfamiliar
or maybe even unknown to people, it's actually more precise than the other choices that I
have.
but the thing that gets me involved in that in the first place is that
is that just words themselves seem to me to be a happy thing, I love words, I get a great
sense of pleasure out of discovering a word that I didn't know before and finding out what it means
and finding out how it can be used, you know, that cheers me up and there are lots of ways in which
I think that if my readers could just hear those words in the spirit in which I put them in the prose,
they would find, for example, that the covenant books aren't as grim in mood as they think they are.
Because I'm shooting out these little gleams of pleasure all the time.
and I wish those could be received in the way they were meant
because then people would, well, like real Musgrave,
you were at the panel yesterday, real is an interesting man
and there are times when he just laughs and chuckles and grins
reading things in my books which are grim
and he knows that they're grim, it's not like he's stupid or insensitive
but he's also picking up some of the other things that I'm trying to project as well
There is an element of joy in those books which balances a lot of the dismay.
And from my point of view, unfortunately, it's conveyed in, it's like being conveyed in code.
It's conveyed through my love of language, and not everybody on the other end receives that message that I'm trying to put out.
